text: Yes, hyperparameter optimization is an area right for overfitting. It no doubt will improve the bias versus variance tradeoff in machine learning. Bias means the error in the training set, and variance means the error in the outer sample. So if you optimize hyperparameters very carefully, no doubt the error in the training set will be very low. You'll be making excellent, accurate predictions. But that could make your outer sample prediction rather poor at the same time. So it is first of all critical to apply coarse validation to hyperparameter optimization. You cannot just hyperparameterize on the training set. You have to make sure that it works on a coarse validated set. The second issue is that we don't over-hyperoptimize. Some people want to run optimization for 1,000, 10,000 iterations. Make it more efficient. Just pick the exact number. We view that as unnecessary and maybe even harmful. So we do a very light parameter optimization. We don't want it to be completely crazy. If the depth of the tree is just set to 1, probably won't work. But setting it to 10,000 probably won't work either. So let's hope a light optimization will find a middle ground somewhere. But we don't have to make sure that the maximum depth is exactly 79 instead of 78.

So if you optimize hyperparameters very carefully, no doubt the error in the training set will be very low.
You'll be making excellent, accurate predictions.
But that could make your outer sample prediction rather poor at the same time.

You cannot just hyperparameterize on the training set.
You have to make sure that it works on a coarse validated set.
The second issue is that we don't over-hyperoptimize.
Some people want to run optimization for 1,000, 10,000 iterations.

Just pick the exact number.

But we don't have to make sure that the maximum depth is exactly 79 instead of 78.
